title: Stars Who've Spoken Out About Getting the COVID-19 Vaccine
author: Johnni Macke
description: See what celebrities including Steve Martin and Martha Stewart have said about receiving the coronavirus vaccine — details
cleaned_text: Experts are hopeful that the [coronavirus](https://www.usmagazine.com/tag/coronavirus/) vaccine will help to curb [the spread of COVID-19](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/stars-who-have-tested-positive-for-coronavirus/), which has killed more than 2 million people worldwide since its 2019 emergence in China. [Steve Martin](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/steve-martin/), [Martha Harris ](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/kamala-harris/)were among the first high-profile names to get the shots. The [Father of the Bride](https://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/pictures/father-of-the-bride-cast-where-are-they-now/) actor [made jokes about the process](https://twitter.com/SteveMartinToGo/status/1350848052379189249) after getting vaccinated in January 2021. "Good news/Bad news," Martin tweeted on I just got vaccinated! Bad news: I got it because I'm 75. Ha!" The comedian noted that it was "smooth as silk" when getting the shot in New York City. He later made light of possible side effects, [tweeting](https://twitter.com/SteveMartinToGo/status/1350859702494781445), "Right now, I'm having no fide resects." Stewart, for her part, [shared a video of herself](https://www.instagram.com/p/CJ693FJhfkX/?utm_source=ig_embed) preparing to get her shot at Mount Sinai Downtown in New York, via Instagram on January 11. "I am so proud of and grateful to the doctors, nurses and medical staff who are wading through the red tape and confusion of the distribution of these very important vaccines," she wrote at the time. "I am excited to have received my dosage and look forward to the booster." The lifestyle guru [clapped back at haters](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/martha-stewart-denies-she-jumped-the-line-to-get-covid-19-vaccine/) who claimed she cut in front of others, writing, "To allay your concerns that I jumped the line, know that I am in the approved age group for this batch of vaccines and I waited in line with others." Stewart, who is 79, added: "Here's to the advancement of science and a heartfelt thanks to those working on the vaccines. We are all hoping for an end to this pandemic." Biden and Harris [had the press in attendance](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nmoY-KhCO6c) when they received their shots, which they both got [ before taking office](https://www.usmagazine.com/stylish/news/joe-biden-will-reportedly-wear-ralph-lauren-to-inauguration/) on January 20. "I'm doing this to demonstrate that people should be prepared, when it's available, to take the vaccine," Biden [told reporters](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VHCQ3cM02DQ) in December 2020. "There's nothing to worry about. I'm looking forward to the second shot." [Ian McKellen](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/ian-mckellen/) and [Joan Collins](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/joan-collins/) were among the first celebrities to [document their vaccine journey](https://www.instagram.com/p/CJ3Iirvlr-8/?utm_source=ig_embed) in the U.K. Collins received her dose on [the same day](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/queen-elizabeth-ii-prince-philip-get-covid-19-vaccines/) as [Queen Elizabeth II](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/queen-elizabeth/), writing on Instagram that she was "honored" to get the shot.
